content: The Act may be cited as the "Renewable Energy Tax Extenders Act" and includes a section on Renewable Energy Credit. The "Renewable Energy Tax Extenders Act" extends various provisions of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 until January 1, 2019. It also includes an expansion of biomass facilities, allowing for new units to be included as part of the facility. The "Renewable Energy Tax Extenders Act" extends provisions of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 until January 1, 2019. It includes an expansion of biomass facilities, allowing new units to be added to increase electricity production. The "Renewable Energy Tax Extenders Act" extends provisions of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 until January 1, 2019, allowing for an increase in electricity production at biomass facilities through the addition of new units. The act also modifies rules for hydropower production, specifying requirements for nonhydroelectric dams. The "Renewable Energy Tax Extenders Act" extends provisions of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 until January 1, 2019, allowing for an increase in electricity production at biomass facilities through the addition of new units. The act also modifies rules for hydropower production, specifying requirements for nonhydroelectric dams that are operated for flood control, navigation, or water supply purposes and do not produce hydroelectric power. The hydroelectric project must maintain water surface elevation to improve environmental quality of the affected waterway. The Secretary, in consultation with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, certifies if a hydroelectric project at a nonhydroelectric dam meets specific criteria. The amendments made by this section apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2008, and also to biomass facilities placed in service after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. Production credit for electricity from marine renewables. Production credit for electricity from marine renewables is amended to include marine and hydrokinetic renewable energy sources such as waves, tides, currents, and free-flowing water in rivers, lakes, and streams. The definition of marine renewables for electricity production includes free-flowing water in irrigation systems, canals, and man-made channels, as well as ocean thermal energy conversion. Exceptions exclude energy derived from dams, diversionary structures, or impoundments for power production. The tax code is amended to include marine and hydrokinetic renewable energy facilities as qualified facilities for tax credits. The facilities must have a capacity of at least 150 kilowatts and be placed in service between the enactment date and January 1, 2019. The credit rate is adjusted accordingly, and coordination with small irrigation power is also addressed. The tax code is amended to include marine and hydrokinetic renewable energy facilities as qualified for tax credits. The effective date for the amendments is the date of the enactment of paragraph (11). SEC. 4. ENERGY CREDIT. The amendments extend the credit for solar energy, fuel cell, and microturbine properties until January 1, 2019 and December 31, 2018 respectively. The effective date for these changes is the date of the enactment of this Act. The amendment extends the credit for geothermal heat pump systems until December 31, 2018, with a 30 percent credit for qualified expenditures. The limitation is set at $2,000 for qualified expenditures. The amendment extends the credit for geothermal heat pump systems until December 31, 2018, with a 30 percent credit for qualified expenditures, capped at $2,000. Qualified geothermal heat pump property expenditure refers to expenses for equipment using ground or ground water for a dwelling unit in the US used as a residence by the taxpayer. The amendment extends the credit for geothermal heat pump systems until December 31, 2018, with a 30 percent credit for qualified expenditures, capped at $2,000. Maximum expenditures for joint occupancy are $6,667 for qualified geothermal heat pump property expenditures. The amendment extends the credit for geothermal heat pump systems until December 31, 2018, with a 30 percent credit for qualified expenditures, capped at $2,000. Maximum expenditures for joint occupancy are $6,667 for qualified geothermal heat pump property expenditures. Effective Date: The amendment applies to property placed in service after December 31, 2008. The Alternative Motor Vehicle Credit under section 30B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is extended until December 31, 2018, with the termination of the credit not applying to property purchased after that date. The limitation on the number of new qualified hybrid and advanced lean-burn technology vehicles eligible for the credit is repealed. The effective dates for these amendments are the date of the enactment of the Act for the extension and for vehicles manufactured after December 31, 2008 for the repeal of the limitation.
